Born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, he showed early interest in acting and received a theater arts degree from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.


Ritter's career spanned over four decades, during which he garnered a loyal fan base and critical acclaim. His versatility as an actor shone through various roles, from serious dramas like "Father of the Bride" (1991) to comedic hits such as "Ghost" (1990) and "Speed" (1994). Off-screen, Ritter was also known for his work with charities and organizations. He was actively involved in the fight against breast cancer, a cause close to his heart following his mother's death from the disease. His philanthropy and personal generosity resonated with the public, adding depth to his public image.
